DEFINITION: A sequence of characters used to identify, name, or characterize a trial or study subject.
A unique identifier for a subject in a study.
Role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in evaluator.
Date of birth of the subject
Unit of age of the subject
Self reported race of the subject
Verbatim name of the observed event
Used to indicate whether the event was pre-specified
Used when the occurrence of specific events is solicited to indicate whether or not a clinical event occurred.
The completion status indicates that a question was not answered.
Describes the reason data was not collected. Used in conjunction with completion_status  when value is NOT DONE.
Anatomical location further detailing distribution. For e.g. ENTIRE, SINGLE, SEGMENT.
The severity or intensity of the event.
Used to indicate whether the event was serious
Description of the outcome of an event.
The serious event associated with congenital anomaly or birth defect.
The serious event resulting in persistent or significant disability/incapacity.
The serious event resulting in death.
The serious event that requires or prolongs hospitalization.
The serious event is life threatening.
Records toxicity grade using a standard toxicity scale (such as the NCI CTCAE). Sponsor should specify which scale and version is used in the Sponsor Comments column of the Define.XML document.
Test code linkage to external or sponsor-defined controlled  terminology
Test name linkage to external or sponsor-defined controlled  terminology
Anatomical location further detailing distribution. For e.g. ENTIRE, SINGLE, SEGMENT.
Used to categorize the result of a finding.
The completion status indicates that a question was not answered.
Describes the reason data was not collected. Used in conjunction with completion_status  when value is NOT DONE.
Name or identifier of the laboratory or vendor who provided the test results.
Defines the type of specimen used for a measurement.
Defines the specific anatomical or biological region of a tissue, organ specimen or the region from which the specimen is obtained, as defined in the protocol
Defines the condition of the specimen
Method of the test or examination
Analysis method applied to obtain a summarized result. Analysis method describes the method of secondary processing applied to a complex observation result
The lead used for the measurement, examples, V1, V6, aVR, I, II, III.
Indicator used to identify fasting status such as Y, N, U, or null if not relevant.
Role of the person who provided the evaluation.
Used to distinguish multiple evaluators with the same role recorded in evaluator.
Text description of time when a measurement or observation should be taken as defined in the protocol.

Planned Elapsed time in ISO 8601 format which is relative to a planned fixed reference. It is to be used when there are repetitive measurements. It is not a clock time or a date/time variable, but an interval.
Evaluation interval associated with an observation, where the interval is not able to be represented in ISO 8601 format
Mode or condition of the record specifying whether the intervention is intended to happen or has happened.
Used to indicate whether the treatment was pre-specified
Used to indicate whether a treatment occurred when information about the occurrence is solicited.
The completion status indicates that a question was not answered.
Describes the reason data was not collected. Used in conjunction with completion_status  when value is NOT DONE.
Amount of treatment in numeric format
Amount of treatment in non-numeric format
Intended schedule or regimen for the Intervention
Intended schedule or regimen for the Intervention
Anatomical location further detailing distribution. For e.g. ENTIRE, SINGLE, SEGMENT.
Indicator used to identify fasting status such as Y, N, U, or null if not relevant.
Amount of an active ingredient expressed quantitatively per dosage unit, per unit of volume, or per unit of weight, according to the pharmaceutical dose form.
Description of reason or explanation of why a dose is adjusted.
Primary indication denotes why a medication was taken or administered.
Adverse event number when primary indication is an adverse event.
Medical history sequence number when primary indication is an event from medical history.
Other indication as primary indication for concomitant medication
Short name of the identifier characteristic of the device (e.g., "SERIAL", "MODEL").
Name of the identifier characteristic of the device.
